meaningMnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means lack, and this verb means to lack something. Pretty simple in English, but 欠く is actually kind of advanced and formal in Japanese, so it's mostly just used in writing. Also keep in mind this is a transitive verb, so 欠く takes a direct object — maybe someone lacks knowledge, for example, or you lack concentration. This is a bit different from saying "your concentration is lacking," at least grammatically. (For that, you'd use 欠ける.)
readingMnemonic:
You learned this reading when you learned 欠ける, but here's a mnemonic just in case:

You never know when you're going <vocabulary>to lack something</vocabulary>. Like a <reading>ca</reading>r (か). Did you plan for it to break? NO! But it happened and now you lack a car in a big way. Not <reading>cool</reading> (く)!
